Biodiesel obtained via the transesterification process, a reaction frequently involving catalysis by homogeneous or heterogeneous catalysts, has shown considerable potential as a supplement to petroleum-based diesel; heterogeneous catalysts in the transesterification of vegetable oils are of special interest as they are relatively safer for the environment besides being endowed with recycling and regeneration attributes. The deployment of heterogeneous catalysts, however, necessitates a higher concentration of catalyst, a greater molar ratio of alcohol to oil, and an elevated temperature and pressure to produce biodiesel. A variety of solid-acid catalysts (SACs) have been utilized in the production of biodiesel, represented by Ti(SO4)O, SO4/Fe‒Al‒TiO2, sulfonated single-wall carbon nanohorns, Ti‒SBA‒15, La‒PW‒SiO2/single-wall carbon nanotubes, ionic liquid grafted NH2‒UiO‒66, ZrFe‒SA‒SO3H, magnetic SACs, sulfonic-reduced graphene oxide, CaO‒Al2O3‒SiO2‒CaSO4, and SiO2@Cs‒SO3H, which are deliberated here. These catalysts are highlighted and discussed in view of their exceptional catalytic activity and recyclability, in addition to comments on the existing challenges and potential future perspectives of the SACs. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Catalyst Solid acids Biofuel Biodiesel Energy Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction For the past two decades, researchers have been looking into renewable energy resources as a means of reducing carbon emissions and satisfying the world's growing demand for energy [1–5]. Biodiesel has gained widespread acceptance as a viable resource due to its biodegradability, accessibility, renewability, nontoxicity, and decreased greenhouse gas emissions, and consequently, it is considered an ideal clean alternative for petrodiesel [6–10]. Biodiesel is a blend of long-chain fatty acid alkyl (methyl or ethyl) esters formed from oils or fats (triglycerides) with qualities comparable to diesel derived from petroleum (gasoil). Biodiesel's primary benefit is that it can readily decompose in landfills in contrast to petroleum-based diesel, and its combustion in diesel engines produces fewer emissions of carbon monoxide (CO), sulfur oxides (SOx), solid particles, and organic molecules [11–15]. Therefore, biodiesel is safer than petroleum diesel in most cases. For biodiesel production, stoichiometric concentrations of strong Brønsted bases like sodium/potassium hydroxides or sodium methoxide are often deployed in the transesterification of triglycerides with methanol or ethanol. However, in order to avoid soap formation from saponification side reactions, this approach calls for the use of raw materials with low water concentrations to prevent catalyst dilution or neutralization by water and low free fatty acid (FFA) contents. When these byproducts are produced, the stoichiometric base is used up, the biodiesel output drops, and the separation of the esters is rendered additionally difficult because of the formation of emulsions [16–20]. Biodiesel can be made from a wide variety of feedstocks, including edible and non-edible vegetable oils, animal fats, and waste cooking oils. Nevertheless, it is undeniable that when biodiesel is made from 100% vegetable oil or animal fat, the cost of the raw oil constitutes roughly 50% of the total production cost. While vegetable oils are frequently used as feedstocks for biodiesel production via transesterification in Europe and the United States, doing so would be prohibitively expensive in countries like China, where most vegetable oils are imported at relatively high prices and are typically utilized for cooking [21–25]. For use as feedstock oils in biodiesel preparation, waste cooking oil (WCO) is typically first transformed into acidified oil, where its FFA level can be as high as 90%. Thus, esterification predominates when the acidified oil is utilized as a raw material to produce biodiesel [26–28]. In order to make biodiesel from low-cost, non-food feedstocks, researchers have focused heavily on improving the design of solid-acid catalysts (SACs). This is due to the fact that SACs can perform both the esterification of FFAs and the transesterification of triglycerides without any of the drawbacks of using liquid acid catalysts, like soap formation. They also make it possible to produce biodiesel continuously, which is an important step for the process intensification. These catalysts are suitable for commercial biodiesel production as they can be recovered and reused after esterifications/transesterifications [29–35]. New synthetic methods are constantly being sought to facilitate the production of SACs with various desired properties. There are many solid acids available today that have been designed to replicate liquid acid functions. Solid acids, however, are frequently less efficient, less stable, and more costly than their liquid counterparts. Many processes have adapted to make use of SACs over the past decade. When compared to liquid acids, which have clearly delineated acidic characteristics, solid acids may have a wide range of acidic sites. Generally speaking, they are divided into groups based on their strength and number of sites, Brønsted or Lewis acidity, and the support's textural characteristics. Nevertheless, because these catalysts are not ideal, phase segregation frequently occurs, and the aqueous phase has the potential to quickly deactivate the SACs, thus necessitating the employment of water-tolerant catalysts [36–41]. This review focuses on the transesterification of different edible and non-edible vegetable oils to make biodiesel using SACs such as Ti(SO4)O, SO4/Fe‒Al‒TiO2, Ti‒SBA‒15, La‒PW‒SiO2/single-wall carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs), Al3+‒SO4 2−/MWCNTs, ionic liquid-grafted NH2‒UiO‒66, functionalized magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs), rGO‒SO3H, CaO‒Al2O3‒SiO2‒CaSO4, Cn‒SiO2‒SO3H, WOx/Al2O3, SiO2@Cs‒SO3H, etc., and highlight their tremendous potential as a future technique of creating alternative fuels. The salient features of this review entail a discussion of the optimal reaction parameters for a variety of SACs employed in the esterification/transesterification processes, encompassing a detailed description of the production of such catalysts and their roles in the reaction pathways (Fig. 1 ). This article provides a practical, critical, and scientific overview of SACs that underscores the current state of biodiesel synthesis. 2 Ti(SO4)O Achieving sustainable development largely depends on the reduction of food waste, and the recycling of used cooking oil (UCO) can make a significant contribution towards this goal. Researchers have found that different types of UCOs have potential in the production of biodiesel due to their availability at low costs, ease of processing, and lack of competition with food resources. Nevertheless, there are definite challenges in this conversion process that can be addressed by the application of an appropriate catalyst [42,43]. An innovative approach for preparing a highly stable and recyclable Ti(SO4)O SAC is described by Gardy et al. [44]. This novel hybrid catalyst has a sulfate group which is covalently bonded to the catalyst's structure. As can be seen in Fig. 2 , the reaction between TiO2 nanoparticles (NPs) and chlorosulfonic acid yields both hydrochloric acid as a by-product and a solid superacidic catalyst, namely Ti(SO4)O. This composite was characterized, and its potential for usage in the transesterification/esterification of UCO to generate biodiesel was explored. Biodiesel yield, catalytic activity, and stability during transesterification/esterification were studied as functions of reaction temperature and time, catalyst loading, methanol to UCO ratio, and feedstock FFA concentration. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and X-ray diffraction (XRD) were utilized to ascertain the catalyst's chemical composition, morphology, stability, particle size distribution, and surface area. Utilizing Ti(SO4)O as a SAC can increase the production of fatty acid methyl ester (FAME) to 97.1% under optimal conditions. It was determined that feedstock with FFA up to 6wt.% was ideally suitable for this catalyst. It appears that the catalyst could be employed for the simultaneous transesterification and esterification of UCO to biodiesel, which might significantly reduce energy consumption compared to several other SACs. Ti(SO4)O could also be recycled and reused up to 8 times without the active sites becoming ineffective. This resulted in significantly better process conditions and greater tolerance to FFA than many other reported metal oxide catalysts. In addition, the biodiesel produced using this method met American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) and European norm criteria, suggesting that it is worth further development toward industrialization. According to XRD analysis of the recycled catalyst, the Ti(SO4)O catalyst retained its structure even after 8 recycles (Fig. 3 ). However, during cycles 9 and 10, a diffraction peak (2θ = 25.32°) associated with the anatase form of TiO2 (101) reflection emerged, affecting process efficiency; the catalyst activity loss was driven by leaching. In light of the encouraging results regarding efficiency, stability, and product quality, the catalysts investigated in this study present themselves as viable contenders worthy of further exploration for potential large-scale implementation. 3 Magnetic SO4/Fe‒Al‒TiO2 The surge in the societal use of plant and animal oils has resulted in the generation of more waste cooking oil (WCO) and its improper disposal through landfills or sewage systems has led to severe environmental problems. With recent technological advancements, it is now possible to utilize WCO as a sustainable feedstock for biofuel production. This method not only maximizes the value of biowastes through energy recovery but also mitigates the ecological challenges associated with WCO disposal [45,46]. Gardy et al. [47] designed and synthesized a multifunctional magnetic solid acid [SO4/Fe‒Al‒TiO2] catalyst to convert WCO into biodiesel. The commercial TiO2 NPs (a mixture of anatase and rutile) were functionalized sequentially with Al2O3 as a buffer layer, followed by the addition of Fe2O3 to impart the catalyst a magnetic feature, and finally sulfation with chlorosulfonic acid to impart Brønsted acidity (Fig. 4 ). For the esterification/transesterification of WCO to biodiesel, SO4/Fe‒Al‒TiO2 displayed promising activity. After reacting for 2.5 h at 90 ºC with 3wt.% catalyst and 10:1 molar ratio of methanol/WCO, the FAME production efficiency was 95.6%. The sensitivity of SO4/Fe‒Al‒TiO2 to FFA in bio-oil feedstocks was also examined by testing its catalytic activity in the transesterification of fresh corn oil spiked with various weight percentages of oleic acid (OA) (Fig. 5a). Interestingly, regardless of the FFA concentration of the oil, the FAME output remained around 95%, indicating it to be an efficient catalyst. Ten consecutive reactions were run to determine the catalyst's durability under ideal conditions (Fig. 5b). The fact that the FAME output remained above 90% after 10 recycles is another proof of the material's excellent stability. Clearly visible [110] facets for the rutile TiO2 NPs can be seen in the TEM image of the recovered used catalyst from the WCO transesterification process after 10 runs. In summary, the catalyst SO4/Fe-Al-TiO2 exhibits efficacy in catalyzing feedstocks that contain 20wt.% or less of FFA, besides demonstrating exceptional stability in the transesterification of WCO. 4 Single-walled carbon nanohorns (SWCNHs) Esterification is an important reaction deployed in organic synthesis as esters are commonly present in both synthetic and natural organic compounds; esterification is a crucial reaction for the production of biofuels such as biodiesel. As a sustainable and eco-friendly alternative to fossil diesel, biodiesel holds great potential in the renewable energy sector [48,49]. Poonjarernsilp et al. [50] used a hydrothermal approach that involved sulfuric acid to sulfonate SWCNHs in order to generate SACs which were then examined for their reactivity in terms of their ability to catalyze esterification, a crucial step in the production of biodiesel. Researchers also investigated the effect of oxidation pretreatment on the efficiency of SWCNH. As a point of reference, they also used sulfonated carbon black (CB) and activated carbon (AC). A sulfuric acid solution was also employed to simulate the typical homogeneous acid catalyst for further evaluation. Scheme 1 depicts the overall reaction strategy for the esterification process. Sulfonation has been shown to enhance the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of SWCNH by a factor of two and decrease the number of pores exceeding 20 nm in SWCNH and oxidized SWCNH (ox‒SWCNH). Fig. 6 shows TEM images of the produced catalysts; the sulfonation-induced structural change was not particularly evident in the TEM study. The esterification findings are shown in Fig. 7 as a function of reaction time in terms of methyl palmitate yield. It is evident that SO3H‒SWCNH has the best catalytic activity. The catalytic activity of the SACs was ranked in order of SO3H‒AC < SO3H‒ox‒SWCNHs < SO3H‒CB < SO3H‒SWCNH. Similar yields have been achieved with both the SO3H‒AC and the homogenous sulfuric acid catalysts. Further, the active sites of SO3H‒AC, SO3H‒CB, SO3H‒ox‒SWCNH, and SO3H‒SWCNH catalysts are not destroyed after repeated use, as measured by the turnover frequency (TOF). As a result, it appears that overuse has lowered the exposed acid sites instead. SO3H‒ox‒SWCNH and SO3H‒SWCNH, on the other hand, have more stable acid sites than CB and AC. The findings suggest that the hydrophobic surface of SO3H-SWCNH, combined with its high acid site density and TOF, makes it an ideal catalyst for palmitic acid esterification to produce methyl palmitate. 5 Ti‒SBA‒15 Production of biodiesel fuel (BDF) from non-edible oils is a viable alternative to diesel fuel, as it is biodegradable, renewable, and has lower greenhouse gas emissions. The conventional technique of producing BDF is via transesterification of edible vegetable oils using methanol, utilizing alkali bases and/or mineral acids as homogeneous catalysts. However, this method can be difficult and costly due to the need for subsequent purification and separation processes, and the competition between BDF and food production is a major concern. In order to achieve greener biodiesel production, the development of efficient SACs and the deployment of non-edible oils have been explored, as these catalysts possess high thermal stability, high activity, and reusability [51,52]. Chen et al. [53] studied the preparation of a high-quality BDF from various edible and non-edible vegetable oils, such as palm fatty acid distillates, crude Jatropha oil, refined rapeseed oil, crude palm oil, and refined soybean oil, using mesoporous Ti‒SBA‒15 catalysts as a weak Lewis SAC. They first created mesoporous substances in a single pot reaction using a range of Ti loadings between 0.808 and 6.78 mol%. When producing high-quality BDF at 200 °C, Ti‒SBA‒15 has been used as a heterogeneous SAC for the simultaneous transesterification and esterification of vegetable oils with methanol. By deploying pulsed NH3 chemisorption, the researchers were able to determine the acid capacity of the catalysts. The predominantly weak Lewis acid characteristics of the Ti‒SBA‒15 catalysts, which originated from the seemingly tetrahedral Ti4+ species, were accompanied by differential heats of NH3 adsorption that were less than 90 kJ mol−1. Fig. 8 depicts the suggested reaction pathway of high-quality BDF preparation over Ti‒SBA‒15. Triglyceride represents the R2COOR1 initial ester, where R1 stands for glycerol and R2 for the long carbon chain of fatty acid. The carbonyl group of the starting ester is coordinated on the Ti4+ species as the suggested active site (I) of Ti‒SBA‒15 catalysts via oxygen atoms to create a Lewis complex, like intermediate (II). As a result of forming hydrogen bonds with lattice oxygens from neighboring tetrahedral Ti4+ species, the H atom on the hydroxyl group is stabilized, presumably activating methanol. To form a tetrahedral intermediate (III), activated methanol must nucleophilically attack the carbonyl group of the Lewis complex. The intermediate (IV) is generated with an ester and alcohol of R2COOCH3 and R1OH, where R2COOCH3 is FAME (BDF), and R1OH is G, MG, or DG. The new alcohol and ester are removed from the tetrahedral Ti4+ species in the last phase, which is followed by the regeneration of the catalytically active sites (I) for the subsequent catalytic cycle. The research also demonstrated that the 3Ti‒SBA‒15 catalyst was capable of being renewed using calcination treatment, even though the catalytic activity and acidic capacity marginally declined after the third regeneration. Overall, the 3Ti‒SBA‒15 catalyst demonstrated FFA and water tolerance levels many times higher than the reference catalysts, and other heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts used in the present-day preparation of BDF. Consequently, this makes 3Ti‒SBA‒15 catalyst a viable option worth exploring in greater detail for potential large-scale applications. 6 Zr-comprising metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) MOFs are porous materials that can adjust their structural topology and pore size to suit the demands of catalytic reactions or conversion pathways. MOFs have remarkable tunability, high surface area, and crystallinity, ranging in size from nano- to micro-scale. However, their catalytic sites are restricted inside their porous framework, thus limiting their effectiveness for biodiesel production. Consequently, the modification of MOFs’ is essential to overcome this limitation [54,55]. Cirujano et al. [56] developed SACs for FFA esterification in order to make biodiesel and other compounds of interest by employing Zr-comprising MOFs with terephthalate (UiO‒66) and 2-aminoterephthalate ligands (UiO‒66‒NH2); several alcohols and unsaturated and saturated FFAs of varying chain lengths have been employed. The direct esterification of FFAs with low molecular weight alcohols (ethanol or methanol) is a recognized alternative procedure to produce biodiesel compatible with feedstock in FFAs (e.g., wastes and by-products from food processing plants or industrial biomass processing), as depicted in Scheme 2 . The findings from the study reveal that UiO‒66‒NH2 is more effective as a catalyst than UiO‒66. This points to the possibility of cooperative acid-base catalysis, where the acid would be activated twice by the coordinatively unsaturated Zr vacancies and the water or alcohol would be eliminated with the help of the material's amino groups, deprotonating the substance. The likely mechanism of the alcohol esterification process over both catalysts is depicted in Figs. 9 a and b. UiO‒66‒NH2 can catalyze esterification because it is a bifunctional acid-base catalyst. The reaction is more efficiently carried out when moderate acid-base pairs are located in close proximity, includind those present in UiO‒66‒NH2. This is so because in this dual activation, it is no longer necessary to have strong individual acid or basic sites to reach high selectivity and activity. UiO‒66‒NH2 is more active than UiO‒66 because the Zr Lewis acid sites can adsorb the fatty acid, enhancing the electrophilic nature of the carboxylic carbon atom. This is how UiO‒66‒NH2 differs from UiO‒66 in terms of its activity. Overall, this work demonstrates that these Zr‒MOFs can be used in the preparation of a wide range of products, including biodiesel compounds (methyl esters and fatty acids ethyl) and other useful entities (e.g., isopropyl palmitate and oleyl oleate), with productivities and catalytic activities comparable to or even superior to those of other SACs. 7 La‒PW‒SiO2/SWCNTs The application of heteropoly acids as solid acid catalysts for transesterification has garnered immense interest, among several other heterogeneous catalysts. Despite being efficient catalysts, they have some drawbacks, namely their poor solubility in polar solvents and low specific surface area, which limit their effectiveness as catalysts. Therefore, to overcome these detriments, many scientists have made efforts to support heteropoly acids on various nanomaterials [57,58]. Using the sol-gel approach, Shu et al. [59] produced a solid Brønsted-Lewis acid catalyst (La‒PW‒SiO2/SWCNTs) by modifying H3PW12O40 (HPW) with single wall carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) functionalized with La3+ and sidewall hydroxyl groups (SWCNTs‒OH). The results showed that methanol to OA mass ratios of 15:1, catalyst amounts of 1.5wt.%, and a reaction temperature of 65 °C after 8 h resulted in a maximum OA conversion of higher than 93%. Furthermore, a maximum of 88.7% OA conversion was achieved after six cycles of La‒PW‒SiO2/SWCNTs. The mechanism of Lewis acid site creation in La‒PW‒SiO2/SWCNT catalyst is schematically depicted in Fig. 10 . Initially, the hydrolysis of tetraethoxysilane (TEOS) took place when it was employed as a source of Si, and the formation of a SiO2 network occurred during the conversion process of sol–gel under acidic circumstances. Second, the (OH2 +Si)+ ions that are present in the SiO2 network were able to coordinate with the H + in the HPW, that led to the formation of the (Si‒OH2+)(H2PW12O40 −) complex, which has a powerful electrostatic adsorption force. After the calcination process, (Si‒OH2+)(H2PW12O40 −) establishes extra bonds with the –OH of SWCNTs‒OH and La3+, resulting in the formation of the active component LaPW12O40‒SiO2. The powerful electron-withdrawing effect of La3+ forces electrons move to the surface of SWCNTs, where they will spread in a manner similar to that of the benzene ring. As a result, the La‒PW‒SiO2/SWCNTs catalyst's predisposition toward a system charge imbalance was exacerbated, leading to an excess of positive charge. Here is why the La‒PW‒SiO2/SWCNT catalyst is much more stable than the La‒PW catalyst. In the esterification between methanol and OA, water is produced, which hydrate the Brønsted acid sites, thus decreasing the catalytic activity. The effects of Lewis acid and acetic acid on the esterification between methanol and OA are depicted in Fig. 11 . This diagram clearly demonstrates that Lewis acid and Brønsted acid sites for esterification catalyze the reaction in fundamentally distinct ways. Overall, this investigation suggests that the La-PW-SiO2/SWCNTs have potential as a cost-effective and efficient catalyst due to their high catalytic performance and stability. 8 Ionic liquid-functionalized magnetic SAC Ionic liquids (ILs) are a type of compound that are characterized by their fluid state at temperatures below 100 °C. Their non-volatile nature makes them an attractive option for deployment as catalysts, solvents, and electrolytes, among other applications. The use of ILs as catalysts for the synthesis of biodiesel has emerged as a promising approach towards achieving a more environmentally friendly and sustainable production process [60,61]. After obtaining an acidic IL (AIL) precursor from (3-aminopropyl)-trimethoxysilane, Li et al. [62] immobilized it onto a magnetic core to create a novel magnetic SAC (Fig. 12 ). With its core-shell architecture, this catalyst allowed reactants easy access to its acid sites on the shell. An IL shell was formed by the affixation of AIL onto a magnetic core via Si‒O‒Si connections. In order to prepare biodiesel from waste oil in a single batch, magnetic solid acid was deployed. The high activity and stability were made possible by the strong ionic connections created by the core-shell structure and magnetic attractions between the particles. Both FFAs and waste frying oil were used to investigate catalytic performance. Waste oil with an FFA content of 22wt.% was employed as the source material after undergoing dehydration and decolorization processes (Fig. 13 ). The processes by which FFAs and triglycerides are transformed were investigated. After 9 h, the magnetic solid acid had a total yield of 99% due to its significant esterification and transesterification activities. The solid catalyst was easily retrieved using a magnet after the completion of the reactions. An investigation on the catalytic activity of recovered solid acid was carried out. After six cycles of recycling, the solid acid's catalytic activity was still above 98% yield. Powerful IL's ionic interactions on the solid surface resulted from the magnetic accumulation of the particles and the maintenance of a specific distance between them due to the steric hindrance of IL. In addition to this, the acid sites were not difficult to reach by the reactants. When compared to filtering, where some catalysts are lost due to adsorption by the filter paper, magnetic separation proved to be a more effective method. In general, this SAC has considerable potential for application in ecofriendly processes because of its high stability, strong catalytic activity, ease of preparation, and magnetic properties. 9 Al3+‒SO4 2−/MWCNTs The application of abundant carbon materials has been extensively utilized in many renewable energy and environmental studies [63]. The functionalization of sulfonic groups on carbon-based catalysts (SCC) generates heterogeneous acids, which are highly desirable for transesterifications in the process of biodiesel production. Covalent attachment of ‒SO3H groups to special carbon structures via C‒SO3H or C‒PhSO3H linkages imparts excellent catalytic activity to SCC. Hitherto, SCC types for biodiesel production include graphene, MWCNTs, AC, BC, graphite oxides, graphitic carbon nitride, and ordered mesoporous carbon [64]. With concentrated sulfuric acid and Al3+, Shu et al. [65] impregnated MWCNTs to create a novel solid Lewis acid catalyst. Since the Lewis acid sites have shown significant catalytic activity for transesterification and esterification, they could increase the stability of SO4 2−/MWCNTs in the associated catalytic reactions. TEM was used to examine SO4 2−/MWCNTs and Al3+‒SO4 2−/MWCNTs, to achieve a clearer understanding of the morphological changes that occurrs in the MWCNTs after they are transformed by concentrated sulfuric acid and Al3+. Figs. 14 a and b show that the examined MWCNTs have a relatively lax structure. However, once MWCNTs are treated with concentrated sulfuric acid and Al3+, the CNTs in the Al3+‒SO4 2−/MWCNTs crosslink with each other. In addition, the SO4 2−/MWCNTs and Al3+‒SO4 2−/MWCNTs catalysts, as shown in Figs. 14c and d, preserve the hollow structure of MWCNTs. The mechanism by which the powerful Lewis acid sites in Al3+‒SO4 2−/MWCNTs are formed is depicted in Fig. 15 . In the process of oxidizing MWCNTs with concentrated sulfuric acid at high temperatures, carboxyl groups and oxygen-containing groups are formed, which already exist in the tube wall. After that, sulfuric acid is used to sulfonate the carboxyl and hydroxyl groups. Al3+ replaces H + because of its strong metallic properties, and then they combine with O2−. The Al3+‒SO4 2−/MWCNTs catalyst has a higher Lewis acidity because a Lewis acid center is created at the site of Al3+ due to the electronic effect of S = O. This suggests that this catalyst would work well for the esterification step in biodiesel synthesis. In summary, this investigation demonstrates that the acid sites on Al3+‒SO4 2−/MWCNTs catalyst consist primarily of Lewis acid, which is beneficial in preventing the Brønsted acid active sites from undergoing hydration. Consequently, this catalyst is well-suited for biodiesel synthesis via esterification. 10 Ionic liquid-grafted NH2‒UiO‒66 Categorization of ILs can be performed on the basis of their acidity, which include basic, acidic, and neutral ILs. Among these, AILs were first synthesized by deploying aromatic and aliphatic amines along with simple Brønsted acids. In the past decade, AILs have garnered significant attention for their application in biomass processing [66]. Lu et al. [67] produced several AIL for their catalytic activities using amino-functionalized MOF NH2‒UiO‒66, as a carrier. The acid-base interaction between the ‒SO3H groups of AIL and the ‒NH2 groups in NH2‒UiO‒66 resulted in the successful preparation of a wide range of AIL-grafted NH2‒UiO‒66 SACs denoted by the generic name xAIL@NH2‒UiO‒66. The preparation process is schematically represented in Fig. 16 . The production process included in-depth research into the mass ratio (x) of AIL/NH2‒UiO‒66, as well as characterization of the catalysts' stability and structure. Excellent catalytic activities have been demonstrated by 3AIL@NH2‒UiO‒66, as evidenced by a biodiesel production at greater than 80% yield and a conversion of FFAs to ester at better than 90% efficiency. The 3AIL@NH2‒UiO‒66 also showed great recyclability, with an OA conversion that dropped from 96.86% to 90.42% over the course of 6 runs. The esterification catalyzed by 3AIL@NH2‒UiO‒66 is depicted in Fig. 17 . In a nutshell, the H + in 3AIL@NH2‒UiO‒66 targets the carbonyl groups in FFAs, converting them into carbocation. As a result, a tetrahedral intermediate is formed when the carbocation is attacked by the nucleophile CH3OH. Subsequently, the tetrahedral intermediate can be broken down into biodiesel and H +. This catalyst, according to its high catalytic activity and ultra-porous structure, is a promising contender for deployment as an industrial-scale heterogeneous SAC in biodiesel synthesis. 11 Grafted fibrous polymer Palm oil is considered a favorable raw material for producing biodiesel, as its properties are similar to those of petro-diesel. However, the use of palm oil as a fuel source has been a topic of controversy due to its role as a food source. To address this issue, numerous studies have explored the potential of using palm oil for biodiesel production. Additionally, the palm oil industry generates a significant amount of residue, both wet and dry, which could be processed to produce biofuels [68,69]. Gamma-ray irradiation method was used by Maleki et al. [70] to attach glycidyl methacrylate monomers to a polypropylene nonwoven polymer fabric. To accomplish the transesterification process and generate biodiesel from palm oil, the grafted polymer was treated with various amino groups and washed with NaOH. Fig. 18 shows a schematic depiction of the catalytic preparation process. Due to radiation grafting, H + and OH− trapped on highly dense bond chains serve as true catalytic sites in polymeric substrates. In addition, the grafted polymer framework is also where the catalytic sites are located. In a transesterification process utilizing a polymer catalyst produced by radiation grafting, the reaction solution's convective flow carries the reactants to the catalytic sites. This means that the inability of the reactants to mass-transfer to the catalytic sites is not a limiting factor. Fig. 19 depicts the chemical process that occurs when triglycerides are subjected to the transesterification procedure, wherein fatty acid alkyl esters and glycerin are produced. To make ethyl or methyl ester as biodiesel, triglycerides are first transformed to diglycerides and then to monoglycerides. Triglycerides and alcohol react with a catalyst in transesterification. Because methyl and ethyl alcohols are most commonly utilized in the process, methyl and ethyl esters are the products of choice. Glycerin, a result of the aforementioned chemical reaction, is deployed in the production of animal feed, medicines, polymers, surfactants, and lubricants. The highest transesterification in this study was achieved using the as-produced catalyst under the optimum conditions of an oil/ethanol molar ratio of 1:200, a reaction time of 3 h, and a reaction temperature of 66 °C. In addition, the temperature was the most influential parameter in determining the biodiesel yield, and the optimum biodiesel yield obtained was 91.6%. After five rounds of catalyst usage in the transesterification and purification processes, a satisfactory yield of ∼79% was attained. The results of this research reveal that the catalyst generated by means of the radiation grafting method has high enough catalytic activity to produce biodiesel efficiently. 12 Acidic ionic liquid polymer When polymers are combined with ILs in a composite, it results in the development of superior materials that combine the unique features of specific polymers and ILs. Moreover, functional groups can be incorporated into the anion, cation, or both, leading to extensive modification of the ILs. Therefore, it is possible to fine-tune the polymer, IL, or both to achieve a diverse range of multifunctional composites that cater to the specific requirements of many applications [71,72]. By combining Brønsted acidic ionic liquid [SO3H (CH2)3VIm] HSO4 with divinylbenzene (DVB), Liang et al. [73] demonstrated a new type of acidic polymeric ionic liquid (PIL) (Fig. 20 ); polymerization of the monomer was performed to verify the synergistic action of the ions. DVB was then used to copolymerize the oligomers. Due to its high polarity, it was challenging to solidify an ionic liquid into a polymer. The high hydrophobic BET surface supplied by DVB was exploited to improve mass transfer efficiency and prevent acid sites from detaching. Under deployed conditions of 3.01 g methanol, 5 g waste oil, and 50 mg catalyst at 70 °C, the influence of reaction time on yield was studied. A close inspection of Fig. 21 reveals that both the esterification and the transesterification processes proceeded smoothly, attesting to the catalyst's effectiveness. After 12 h, the first rapid reaction had reached equilibrium, and there was no noticeable difference in the yield. At first, the transformation from rapeseed oil to biodiesel took little time. It's well understood that there were three stages to the transesterification; glycerol, monoglycerides, and diglycerides were synthesized from the triglycerides. Initially, the catalyst showed some selectivity toward diglycerides and monoglycerides, but the value was completely random. The esterification followed at the same time, although the water byproduct slowed down the process. Additionally, the FFA was entirely converted to biodiesel by the catalyst's hydrophobic surface, which also boasted excellent water resistance. Alternatively, the yield dropped after 12 h when the opposite reaction occurred. The PIL had significantly more activity for the hydrophobic surface, which prevents water from reacting with the acid sites, than the acidic ionic liquid, with the conversion below 96%. In terms of recyclability, the findings reveal that the PIL possessed great stability, and the yield remained unaltered even after the PIL had been recycled a total of six times. In general, this catalyst shows promise for future study with widespread anticipated applications. 13 ZrFe‒SA‒SO3H The utilization of magnetic nanocatalysts has become a burgeoning area for the advancement of sustainable and eco-friendly procedures. The employment of magnetic separation not only eliminates the prerequisite for catalyst centrifugation or filtration subsequent to the reaction's completion, but also facilitates practical methodologies for catalyst recovery. The incorporation of functional groups onto magnetic nanoparticles serves as the foundation for the efficient separation of heterogeneous catalysts from the reaction system using magnetic separation technology, thereby bridging the gap between heterogeneous and homogeneous catalytic processes. Consequently, this can significantly enhance production efficiency while minimizing energy consumption [74,75]. Wang et al. [76] produced the sulfonated magnetic SACs (ZrFe‒SA‒SO3H) with both Lewis and Brønsted sites, which offered together substantial magnetization and a high density of surface acidity. The simplified scheme for making ZrFe‒SA/CMC‒SO3H catalysts is shown in Fig. 22 . For Zr1Fe0.5/1/1.5‒CMC‒SO3H and Zr0.5/1/3.0Fe0.5/1/1.5‒SA‒SO3H, the Zr subscript of 0.5/1/3 indicates ZrOCl2 solution concentrations, and the Fe subscript of 0.5/1/1.5 means Fe2(SO4)3 solution concentrations. A fresh catalyst is depicted in the TEM image in Fig. 23 . Particle sizes of ∼20–70 μm, with irregular forms and apparent carbon stacking, characterized the surface of the fresh catalyst. However, after five catalytic cycles, the catalyst surface seemed smoother, probably as a result of the physical friction that occurred during the reactions. Fig. 23 also shows nano Fe3O4 that is tightly wrapped around the Zr4+ chelated carbon shell. The catalytic activity of as-prepared catalysts was also analyzed. For the purpose of esterifying OA into biodiesel, all tested catalysts demonstrated high levels of activity (92.7–99.5%). Nevertheless, the optimum catalytic reusability was observed for Zr1Fe1‒SA‒SO3H, which had the optimal embedding ratio of Fe and Zr atoms. After five successive cycles of Zr1Fe1‒SA‒SO3H, a high biodiesel yield of 90.3% could still be attained. This hybrid can, therefore, be taken into consideration for additional developments in terms of potential commercial processes. 14 Propyl‒SO3H functionalized graphene oxide (GO‒PrSO3H) GO has garnered significant interest in recent years from researchers in various scientific disciplines, including chemistry, physics, and material science, due to its remarkable chemical modifiability, physical properties, and possible applications across diverse fields. Its two-dimensional configuration reduces the resistance to penetration and enhances mass transfer. Furthermore, the abundance of oxygen-rich functional groups on GO plays a crucial role in chemical reactions [77,78]. GO‒PrSO3H was synthesized and completely described by Masteri-Farahani et al. [79], who then tested its catalytic activity in three different reactions: benzaldehyde acetalization with ethylene glycol, biodiesel synthesis via OA esterification with methanol, and acetic acid esterification with n-butanol. Fig. 24 depicts the steps required to make the GO-based acid catalyst. Since it has a thiol group, (3-mercaptopropyl)-trimethoxysilane was initially chosen as the silylating reagent of choice. To avoid a potential side reaction in which the silyl groups couple to each other via hydrolysis when there's water present, instead of interacting with the ‒OH groups on the GO surface, the reaction was carried out in dry toluene. Finally, ‒SH groups were converted to sulfonic acid functionality under mild reaction conditions using hydrogen peroxide as the oxidizing reagent, followed by acidification with sulfuric acid. Its catalytic behavior in both acetalization and esterification processes was examined in order to demonstrate the versatility of the developed graphene-based acid catalyst. As a result, this catalyst performed superbly (94%) when used to esterify acetic acid with n-butanol. Another key component of biodiesel, methyl oleate, was successfully esterified from OA with methanol using this SAC. In addition, it was shown through the catalyst's reusability that this SAC may be recycled at least five times before losing activity in catalyzing either the acetalization or esterification processes. Reaction pathways for acetalization and esterification using the GO‒PrSO3H catalyst are depicted in Fig. 25 . The carbonyl group of carboxylic acid accepts an acidic proton from the catalyst to generate carbocation, as shown in esterification. The water is then removed from the structure, and the desired ester is produced, owing to the nucleophilic attack of the oxygen atom of the alcohol on the created intermediate. After the reaction is complete, the proton is recycled back to the catalyst. The acetalization begins like the esterification, when the carbonyl group of benzaldehyde absorbs an acidic proton from the catalyst, forming a carbocation on the central carbon atom and opening it up to the subsequent nucleophilic attack of the oxygen atom of ethylene glycol. Oxonium is generated when the connected oxygen of ethylene glycol transfers its proton to a nearby hydroxyl group. Lastly, it is suggested that the other hydroxyl group of ethylene glycol binds to the central carbon to provide the necessary acetal and that the migration of acidic protons to the catalyst structure maintains the catalytic cycle. Thus, incorporation of propyl sulfonic acid groups on the surface of graphene oxide can produce a stable and highly efficient acid catalyst (GO‒PrSO3H) with high surface acidity. However, additional investigations are still required to determine its true potential for scalability and improving efficiency. 15 Sulfonated carbon Durian, a tropical seasonal plant species known locally as the "king of fruits," is a dicotyledonous plant by nature. Currently, durian residues are commonly disposed of through burning or landfills without regard for environmental consequences, such as the contamination of underlying water channels. Durian peels are rich in chemical components such as pigments, cellulose, simple glycosides, coumarins, triterpenes, flavonoids, phenolic acids, phenolic glycosides, as well as esters, and acid compounds. Hence, it appears to be a promising candidate for use as a biodiesel feedstock [80,81]. Leesing et al. [82] created an integrated biorefinery concept employing durian peel (DP) to produce carbon-supported single-atom catalysts (SC‒SAC), yeast lipid, and biodiesel (Fig. 26 ). Acid hydrolysis was used on dried DP to produce a solid fraction called DP hydrolysis residues (DPSF) and a liquid fraction called DP hydrolysate (DPH). Yeast lipid production was stimulated by the oleaginous yeast Rhodotorula mucilaginosa KKUSY14 that utilized DPH, which is rich in fermentable sugars, as a carbon substrate. To make SC‒SAC (DPSF‒SO3H), the DPSF was sulfonated in a single step. Next, to produce biodiesel (SY14‒FAME), R. mucilaginosa KKUSY14 was subjected to direct transesterification (DT) in a wet cell, deploying the SC‒SAC as a catalyst. The influence of catalyst loading on SY14-FAME yield is depicted in Fig. 27 a. The SY14-FAME yield was improved from ∼34.7% to 52.8% when the catalyst loading was raised from 3wt.% to 9wt.% in a microwave-assisted DT (MDT) reaction with a 5:1 methanol/wet cell ratio, for 10 min. A drop in SY14-FAME yield was seen, however, as the amount of catalyst used was enhanced from 12wt.% to 15wt.%. The reaction was also studied using a 5:1 methanol to wet cell ratio in water bath-assisted DT (WBDT) at 65 °C for 1 h. Increasing the catalyst dosage from 3 wt.% to 12 wt.% raised the FAME yield from 58.56% to 70.31%. Up to 15wt.% of catalyst resulted in a drop in SY14‒FAME yield of 63.34%. Under WBDT, the yield of SY14‒FAME was not significantly different when employing a 9wt.% or 12wt.% catalyst; hence, the latter value was chosen for future investigation. The influence of the methanol/wet cell ratio on SY14‒FAME yield is depicted in Fig. 27b. Based on the data, it appears that the best methanol/wet cell ratio for WBDT and MDT is 10:1. Also, 10 min for MDT and 60 min for WBDT were chosen as optimum periods (Fig. 27c), as it is economically advantageous to produce a high FAME yield expeditiously. As can be seen in Fig. 27d, the catalyst's activity decreases with each cycle of reuse, suggesting that this catalyst is not highly reusable. By the sixth MDT reaction cycle, the yield of SY14‒FAME had dropped from 81.57% to 39.56%. Over the course of the first five cycles of reaction in WBDT, the SY14‒FAME yield dropped from 78.73% to 61.04%. Nevertheless, DPSF‒SO3H catalyst may be efficiently recycled twice in WBDT and MDT with minimal activity loss. Consistent with the findings, this idea has economic significance because it reduces or eliminates waste while simultaneously producing entities with added value. 16 Phosphomolybdic acid (HPA)/chitosan (Cs) Pomegranate is a widely cultivated fruit that has a multitude of applications in both the pharmaceutical and food industries. The oil extracted from pomegranate seeds is well-known for its numerous functional and health-promoting properties. Interestingly, the non-edible oil extracted from unripe and spoiled pomegranates that are unsuitable for consumption can be used to produce added value chemicals [83,84]. For the purpose of making biodiesel from pomegranate seed oil, Helmi et al. [85] synthesized the HPA/Cs catalyst. A one-step process with modifications was used to prepare HPA/Cs, as shown in Fig. 28 . The synthesized catalyst was then analyzed using FTIR, XRD, X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF), energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX), and a field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM). The catalyst was utilized in the microwave-assisted transesterification of pomegranate oil, and the biodiesel production procedure was enhanced using response surface methodology and central composite design (RSM-CCD). Fig. 29 shows how varying the reaction time, methanol/oil molar ratio, and catalyst weight affect the resulting biodiesel production. Increases in catalyst concentration from 0.15wt.% to 1.25wt.% and the methanol-to-oil molar ratio from 3.3:1 to 6:1 led to a substantial increase in the biodiesel yield. As a result of the improved interaction between methanol and pomegranate oil, the biodiesel output increased to 88%. The HPA/Cs catalyst may have a role in this enhancement because of its large specific surface area. When the catalyst weight is greater than 1.25wt.%, however, the mass transfer barrier of the reaction system rises, making the biodiesel more viscous and more difficult to stir. After being subjected to 6 cycles, biodiesel production dropped from 90% to 71% in terms of its recyclability. For this reason, HPA/Cs has a yield of 81.66% when used to produce biodiesel and may be recycled and reused six times. Research shows that the physiochemical properties of the pomegranate biodiesel produced are well within ASTM standards, making it a promising diesel alternative. It can be concluded that the utilization of phosphomolybdic acid/Cs as a catalyst exhibits significant promise for the mass production of biodiesel. 17 Natural phosphate-supported TiO2 (TiO2/NP) Since the production of biodiesel involves an intriguing process of esterification of long-chain carboxylic acids, particularly OA, the presence of this and other FFA can vary in different feedstocks, including recycled materials. While transesterifications can be utilized for these feedstocks, acid catalysts are more effective than their base counterparts. As a result, the search for active catalysts for both reactions has been incessant [86,87]. By supporting TiO2 (2.5–10wt.%) on NP, Essamlali et al. [88] created a new SAC. Using titanium isopropoxide as a precursor, the catalyst was synthesized using a sol-gel process and then characterized by deploying assorted physicochemical methods. The produced catalyst's activity was studied in OA esterification with methanol in a batch reactor at autogenous pressure. Many influencing variables were fine-tuned to ensure the highest possible methyl oleate output. Furthermore, the reusability of the catalyst was examined as well. The esterification processes were carried out in a stainless steel (300 mL) batch reactor equipped with a temperature controller, mechanical stirrer, and sample outlet, all of which were operated under autogenous pressure (Fig. 30 ). Multiple chemical stages that could constitute an OA esterification process are depicted in Fig. 31 . Ti species present on the NP support can function as Lewis acids to catalyze the esterification of OA. At first, an OA molecule is adsorbed onto the catalytic surface, where it interacts with the acidic site to produce an electron-deficient carbon through the carbonyl oxygen of OA. When oxygen from the methanol reacts with the newly formed carbocation, a tetrahedral intermediate is formed, which underwent an internal rearrangement and had a water molecule removed, to produce methyl oleate. Under the circumstances of methanol/OA (molar ratio of 8:1), catalyst loading of 10wt.%, reaction temperature of 150 °C, and reaction time of 8 h, TiO2(10)/NP calcined at 800 °C showed the highest catalytic activity and afforded a conversion of 87%. TiO2(10)/NP-800 catalyst also showed good reusability and stability, as its activity was not significantly diminished after being used 6 times. The results show that the FFA concentration in low-cost feedstock may be greatly reduced using a TiO2(10)/NP catalyst, making it a promising choice for the esterification of FFA in highly acidic feedstocks. 18 SnO2‒based SAC Over the past few years, the availability of glycerol, a by-product of biodiesel production, has risen significantly. This waste accounts for about 10% of the total produced biodiesel, as it is generated during the transesterification process. Consequently, the conversion of glycerol into other products with high-added value has become a subject of great importance [89,90]. Mallesham et al. [91] synthesized eco-friendly SACs, like SO4 2−/SnO2, MoO3/SnO2, WO3/SnO2, and SnO2, for producing bioadditive fuels from bioglycerol. The samples obtained in this manner were then systematically evaluated using a number of different characterization methods, namely inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES), Barrett−Joyner−Halenda (BJH) pore size distribution, NH3-temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), FTIR, XPS, BET, and XRD. The most effective SAC was identified for the esterification of glycerol with acetic acid (Figs. 32 a and b), and the results are displayed in Fig. 33 a. As opposed to the further esterification of monoacetin into di- and tri-acetins, the synthesis of monoacetin via glycerol esterification is rather straightforward. Therefore, the rate of conversion to di- and tri-acetin products served as a reference for the catalytic effectiveness of these solid acids. The addition of promoters to SnO2 greatly enhances its catalytic performance, as shown by the activity results (Fig. 33a). When compared to the other solid acids tested, SO4 2−/SnO2 showed the most selectivity toward the di- and tri-acetins and the highest glycerol conversion. Over SO4 2−/SnO2, MoO3/SnO2, WO3/SnO2, and SnO2 solid acids, the obtained glycerol conversions were 89%, 71%, 66.3%, and 41.6%, respectively. Results from an investigation into the catalytic effectiveness of SnO2-based solid acids for the acetalization of glycerol with benzaldehyde are depicted in Fig. 33b. All solid acids demonstrated significant product selectivity and catalytic activity toward 5- and 6-membered acetals, as seen in the graph. Surprisingly, promoted SnO2 solid acids outperformed pristine SnO2 in terms of catalytic activity. The conversions of glycerol over the SO4 2−/SnO2, MoO3/SnO2, WO3/SnO2, and SnO2 catalysts, respectively, were determined to be 77%, 69%, 61%, and 48%. In light of this, the SO4 2−/SnO2 sample demonstrated exceptional catalytic activity among the investigated SACs for both acetalization and esterification of glycerol, mostly as a result of the existence of sufficient superacidic sites. It's interesting to note that SO4 2−/SnO2 catalytic performance significantly declined after being used repeatedly for both reactions. The observed catalytic deactivation of the SO4 2−/SnO2 solid acid is found to be mostly caused by a decrease in the exposed acidic sites, along with an increase in crystallite size, and a decrease in BET surface area. While this catalyst shows outstanding performance in bioglycerol esterification and acetalization, additional research is required to enhance the material's durability for potential large-scale applications over multiple cycles of use. 19 Magnetic poly(glycidyl methacrylate) Wastewater from various sources, such as kitchens, restaurants, slaughterhouses, and food processing plants, contains a significant amount of fat, oil, and grease (FOG) which can be a promising source of biodiesel feedstock due to its availability at no cost. Consequently, there has been an increasing interest among researchers in utilizing such low-cost oils with high FFA content as feedstock for biodiesel production [92,93]. Zillillah et al. [94] discovered that nano-sized SACs composed of iron oxide cores surrounded by poly(glycidyl methacrylate) (PGMA) shells with sulfonic acid surfaces are extremely stable, active, and recyclable. Fig. 34 depicts the esterification scheme of FFA in grease using methanol over such catalysts. In the first stage, FFA is esterified with a nano-sized SAC in grease containing methanol; in the second stage, the residual triglycerides are transesterified with a base catalyst. Moreover, the process for creating SACs at the nanoscale is depicted in Fig. 35 . Iron oxide is used as the central component of the catalysts, which also include a coating shell and sulfonic acid functional groups on the surface. The magnetic iron oxide cores were coated with three different components: silica (Si), polystyrene (PS), and PGMA. These coatings serve two purposes: they shield the magnetic iron oxide cores from environmental damage, and they supply the surface functional groups needed to connect the sulfonic acid moieties. The time-course of FFA esterification in grease using methanol and a variety of SACs is shown in Fig. 36 . More than 80% of FFA was converted within 2 h when utilizing 4wt.% of the micro- and nano-size SACs, demonstrating their effectiveness. PS‒cat (m) 16 (sulfonation agent: 18 M H2SO4, T: 40 °C, time: 1.5 h, size: 60–500 μm), PS‒cat 12 (sulfonation agent: 18 M H2SO4, T: room temperature, time: 0.25 h, size: 80 nm), and PGMA‒cat 4 (sulfonation agent: 0.8 M Na2SO3, T: 80 °C, time: 24 h, size: 90 nm) displayed exceptional performance in attaining 96% FFA conversion, which corresponds to a decrease in FFA content in grease from 16wt.% to lower than 0.5wt.%. In addition, PGMA‒cat 4 outperformed PGMA‒cat (m) 15 (sulfonation agent: 0.8 M Na2SO3, T: 80 °C, time: 24 h, 60–350 μm) in terms of activity and recyclability. The PGMA‒cat 4 esterification product was readily converted to biodiesel using typical base-catalyzed transesterification, yielding FAME in an isolated yield of 88% with 100% purity. The study proposes a low-cost method for producing biodiesel from waste grease through a novel nano-sized SAC. The economic feasibility of this process makes it worthy of further investigation for industrial-scale applications. 20 Sulfonated mesoporous carbon (MC) The esterification of fatty acids can be efficiently catalyzed by MC. This material boasts numerous SO3H acid groups, which make it a versatile catalyst for solid acid applications in biomass conversion. In addition, the mesopores present in the MC facilitate the transportation of large biomass substrates and target products. The carbon's hydrophobicity enhances the hydrothermal stability of the catalyst, which is critical given that biomass conversion often takes place in polar circumstances, such as water. Moreover, the hydrophobicity also enables reactant adsorption and facilitates the desorption of H2O evolved during the conversion process. Further exploration of this SAC can lead to appliances in various industrial processes [95,96]. According to Chang et al. [97], a SAC comprising carbon can be used well in the catalytic synthesis of biodiesel. Sulfonated MC catalyst production through the soft-template approach is depicted in Fig. 37 . Formaldehyde and resorcinol, which served as the carbon precursors, were polymerized into a soluble resin with a low molecular weight in step 1. Hydrogen bonding between ‒OH groups in the precursor resin and PEO-chains in the template led to the formation of a mesoporous complex upon interaction between the carbon precursor and the structure guiding agent (F127). Since the thermal stability of the cross-linked mesoporous complex was greater than that of the template, the latter could be removed by further heat treatment in a N2 atmosphere without causing the pore structure to collapse. Meanwhile, MC SACs were produced by carbonizing the polymer framework via additional heat treatment in a N2 atmosphere. To make MC‒SO3H SACs, step 3 involved heating concentrated sulfuric acid in Teflon autoclaves. For the esterification of OA with methanol, Fig. 38 displays the catalytic performance of the produced sulfonated MC catalysts. Only about 17% of the OA was converted during a 3 h reaction using MC‒7‒SO3H (7 stands for a 700 °C carbonization temperature), which can be attributed to the compound's lack of acidity. The acidity of sulfonated MC was obviously increased as the carbonization temperature was lowered. As a result, their catalytic performances in the esterification were enhanced; ∼40% and 50% OA conversions were obtained employing the MC‒6‒SO3H and MC‒5‒SO3H catalysts, respectively. The maximum catalytic activity was produced by the MC‒4‒SO3H catalyst, and the associated OA conversion was ∼75%. This catalyst's superior activity for biodiesel generation has been attributed to its large acidity capacity and large pore diameters in the mesoporous structure. It was also possible to regenerate the used MC‒4‒SO3H SAC using a straightforward process, enabling recycling and reuse for at least five cycles without leaching of functional groups and maintaining the catalytic stability and activity. Thus, it can be inferred that the sulfonated MC that underwent low-temperature carbonization (at 400 °C) exhibits remarkable acidity and catalytic activity, as well as superb reusability. Furthermore, this type of sulfonated MC still preserves its vast surface area and mesoporous structure, both of which serve as significant factors in boosting catalytic performance. 21 Phosphotungstic acid-functionalized MNPs Developing new catalysts appears to be a viable solution to overcome the major technical hurdles involved in converting grease into biodiesel. The conventional method of using base catalysis proves to be ineffective in this regard, as it leads to the formation of soap due to the interaction between the base and FFA in grease. Hence, alternative catalysts are required to achieve efficient conversion of grease into biodiesel [98]. As a new magnetic SAC for esterification/transesterification of grease, Zillillah et al. [99] described the synthesis and characterization of phosphotungstic acid-functionalized magnetic nanoparticles made up of a poly(glycidyl methacrylate) (PGMA) shell, an iron oxide MNP core, and a HPW surface. The general procedures for creating phosphotungstic acid-functionalized (HPW‒PGMA) MNPs are shown in Fig. 39 . The concurrent esterification and transesterification in a single pot were used to make biodiesel from grease, as presented in Fig. 40 . Grease (21.3wt.% FFAs) was efficiently converted to biodiesel (FAMEs) using HPW‒PGMA MNPs with particle sizes of 90 nm as a catalyst for the simultaneous esterification of FFAs and transesterification of triglycerides with methanol. At 4wt.% catalyst loading and 122 °C for 24 h, a 98% FAME yield was observed, with 96% esterification conversion and greater than 98% transesterification conversion. After being exposed to a magnetic field, HPW‒PGMA MNPs were readily isolated from the reaction mixture and employed again and again, with a 95% productivity retention rate after 10 transformation cycles. This magnetic SAC is thus superior to other reported SACs in terms of recyclability and catalytic performance in this sort of transformation. Therefore, it has the potential to be applied to the production of biodiesel from UCO in a way that is both environmentally and economically beneficial. 22 Macroporous cation-exchange resin Cation-exchange resin is a cost-effective heterogeneous catalyst for esterification that is composed of copolymers of divinyl benzene, styrene, and sulfonic acid groups. Their catalytic activity is dependent on their swelling properties, which control the reactants' accessibility to the acid sites and overall reactivity [100]. To facilitate the esterification of FFAs in the synthesis of biodiesel, Fu et al. [101] prepared macroporous resin catalysts with varying levels of porogen and cross-linking degree (CLD). Catalytic performance was investigated by performing esterification at various temperatures and methanol/FFAs ratios. Higher surface area resin catalysts were shown to be more effective at temperatures greater than 95 °C. Furthermore, when the methanol/FFAs ratio was roughly 15:1, conversions of 97.8% for the macroporous resin and 97.5% for the gel-type catalysts were obtained. Within the framework of their research and discussion, the authors proposed two new ideas. The first one is referred to as "original water" (or "rH2O" for short), and it represents any water already present in the feedstock oil. The latter is referred to as "produced water," or "pH2O," and is the water that results from the esterification of FFAs. As seen in Fig. 41 a, rH2O absorbs onto the ‒SO3H, which is fairly stable and can block FFAs and even methanol from binding to the active sites. The Eley-Rideal mechanism, proposed to explain heterogeneous esterification, argues that the conversion of FFAs is affected by the absorption of reagents on the active sites. In contrast, as shown in Fig. 41b, pH2O is rapidly disseminated across several phases after generation, reducing its likelihood of absorption on the resin surface. This suggests that those water sources might use distinct deactivation mechanisms for the resin catalysts. By comparing the values of pH2O (dashed lines in Fig. 41c and d), it can be seen that the acid value of the macroporous resin ends up being lower than that of the gel-type resin. This finding supported the reaction model presented in Fig. 41b, which suggested that a larger concentration of FFAs would compete for the active sites with pH2O, hence dampening the pH2O-induced deactivation impact of the water. These encouraging results, including the associated catalysts, can be employed in industrial settings if the physical stability of the macroporous resin can be increased through future optimization of the synthesis procedure. 23 Reduced graphene oxide (rGO)‒SO3H Although GO NPs are endowed with excellent properties, their utilization is restricted due to their low temperature stability. However, partial reduction of GO can enhance its thermal stability and convert it to rGO. The acquired rGO exhibits immense potential for application in energy storage and conversion technologies due to its unique physicochemical properties and accessibility, making it the most intriguing carbon NP among the wide variety of nanomaterials available. In addition to energy storage and conversion, rGO finds usage in several other applications such as sorbents, catalysts, chemical and biological processes [102]. Santos et al. [103] used rGO‒SO3H to create a SAC that is both effective and reusable (Figs. 42 a-c). By performing an electrophilic aromatic substitution with fuming sulfuric acid on the surface of rGO, they were able to bind a large number of sulfonic groups covalently. There were three steps to obtain the catalyst. First, the modified Hummer's approach was used to prepare GO from graphite, followed by exfoliation. The oxygen groups of GO were then reduced with NaBH4, and the functionalization was completed using fuming sulfuric acid. The generation of biodiesel was studied using various levels of rGO‒SO3H SACs and periods of reaction (Fig. 43a). After 30 min of reaction time, the biodiesel production was 44% at a catalyst loading of 3wt.%. However, the yield increased to 97% after 1 h. The significant change in biodiesel synthesis that occurs when the reaction time is increased from 30 min to one hour also occurs when a lower catalyst loading is used (1 and 2wt.%). The production of biodiesel, on the other hand, was not significantly impacted when the reaction time was raised from 2 to 3 h for all three catalyst loadings of 1, 2, and 3wt.%. In addition, the results of the recyclability test demonstrate that the yield decreased to only 95% after the fifth cycle (Fig. 43 b); hence, rGO‒SO3H SAC demonstrates a superb stability and catalytic activity in 5 reaction cycles within 3 h of reaction time. The beneficial catalytic capabilities of rGO‒SO3H are attributed to its two-dimensional structure as well as the distribution of a very homogeneous density of –SO3H acid sites over the surface of rGO. These characteristics endorse an increase in catalytic performance and a greater dispersion of reactants. 24 CaO–Al2O3–SiO2–CaSO4 Calcium carbide residue (CCR) is a waste produced in large quantities during the hydrolysis of calcium carbide to generate acetylene, and it contains a significant amount of calcium hydroxide [Ca(OH)2]. This waste material has numerous potential applications, namely for soil stabilization, as a cementing agent and binder, for CO2 capture, and in various chemical processes [104–106]. With a sulfonation technique and thermal modification, Ajala and co-workers [107] were able to create SACs from CCR at a reasonable cost. Anhydrite-based SACs (ASACs) were synthesized as ASAC500, ASAC700, and ASAC900, respectively, by a two-step procedure involving thermal treatment of the CCR at 500, 700, and 900 °C followed by sulfonation (Fig. 44 ); ASACs and CCR were then characterized using BET, SEM, and XRD. According to their findings, ASAC900 has the largest surface area (98.22 m2 g -1), lowest basic density (4.07 mmol g -1), and highest acid density (12.03 mmol g -1). At a constant reaction period of 120 min, catalyst loading of 5wt.%, reaction temperature of 60 °C, and MeOH/lard molar ratio of 12:1, the ASAC500 produced the highest biodiesel yield at 94.8%, followed by the ASAC700 at 89.2%, and the ASAC900 at 98.9%. FAME yields for the waste lard-biodiesel (WLB) samples, namely WLB500, WLB700, and WLB900, all followed the same trend, coming in at 97.16%, 82.67%, and 98.83% (WLBx corresponds to the ASACx). Compared to the ASAC700, which yielded 84.9% biodiesel after the sixth cycle, the ASAC900 and ASAC500 demonstrate relatively good stability by providing 94.7% and 90.4% biodiesel yield after the seventh cycle, respectively. The possible transesterification mechanism of the as-synthesized catalysts is depicted in Fig. 45 . According to the hypothesized mechanism, Lewis base (B) and Lewis acid (A) sites are responsible for catalyzing these reactions. The adsorption of the reactants onto the catalyst system marks the start of the catalytic process (step I). The Lewis basic site then removes the hydrogen from the methanol molecule, creating the methoxide ion (step II). This forms the intermediate by bonding to the carbonyl carbon of the triglyceride molecule, and its reconfiguration produces a FAME molecule and a diglyceride ion. The catalyst surface's basic site, from which hydrogen is extracted, acts to stabilize the diglyceride anion. Each time the diglyceride is converted to monoglyceride and ultimately to glycerol, a new molecule of FAME is created (Step III). In total, three FAME molecules and one glycerol molecule are generated (step IV). The mechanism also predicted an esterification that would transform FFA into FAME. The FFAs undergo this change by adsorbing onto the acidic sites of the catalyst, where their C = O group reacts with the acid site (step VI). As a result, a carbocation is formed (step VII), and the methanol molecule can be attached (step VIII). As can be seen in stage IX, a rearrangement occurs, resulting in the creation of a single molecule of FAME and a single molecule of water (step X). Both the basic and acidic sites of the catalyst were recovered at the end of the simultaneous reactions, as shown in step V. The positive findings from this study suggest that deploying the CCR to produce ASACs may help bring down the price of making biodiesel. Especially, the CCR from factories’ wastes could be a superior material for creating cheap catalysts for mass manufacturing of biodiesel. 25 Cn‒SiO2‒SO3H Hybrid organic-inorganic materials have recently garnered a lot of attention. Silica is considered to be one of the most suitable solid carriers because of the higher number of silanol groups present on its surface, which facilitates the covalent binding of various organic molecules. This property renders silica a particularly attractive material for the production of these hybrid materials [108]. To achieve the desired catalytic and amphiphilic qualities, silica NPs were functionalized by Yang et al. [109] by grafting inert alkyl chains (C3, C8, and C18) and active propylsulfonic acid residues. In two steps, Aerosil® 200 was transformed into amphiphilic silica catalysts coated with alkyl residues and propylsulfonic acid. Silanol condensation of (3-mercaptopropyl)trimethoxysilane (MPTMS) and alkyltrimethoxysilane was used to covalently bind thiol and alkyl functional groups to the silica NPs, and the thiol residues were then oxidized (Fig. 46 ). The resultant NPs are designated Cn‒SiO2‒SO3H, where n is the chain length of alkyl residues in the molecule and um-SiO2 refers to the unmodified SiO2 NPs. It was found experimentally that C18‒SiO2‒SO3H (with a degree of grafting of 48% and a C18/SO3H molar ratio of 54:46) provided the best balance between active (sulfonic acids) and inert (alkyl chains) surface functional groups necessary to get amphiphilic and catalytic characteristics. The transesterification of a number of vegetable oils, including corn, linseed, olive, and safflower, was performed to broaden the use of this catalytic system. C8‒ and C18‒SiO2‒SO3H NPs were utilized as emulsifiers and catalysts in each case. C18‒SiO2‒SO3H NP-stabilized MeOH/sunflower oil Pickering emulsions were also used as a benchmark for comparison. Fig. 47 depicts the data that were collected as a result. It is abundantly obvious that the amphiphilic C18‒SiO2‒SO3H NPs provided the best possible catalytic performance in each and every scenario. However, it is important to highlight that despite the catalytic activity, such a system involves the synthesis of catalyst, its recovery by centrifugation, and the elaboration of the emulsion, all of which can limit its adoption on an industrial scale. 26 WOx/Al2O3 Heterogeneous catalysts have gained popularity for the transesterification of vegetable oils and FFAs with alcohols. With the upsurge of restaurants worldwide, the production of WCO has also increased, causing serious disposal and water treatment problems. These waste oils can also pose health risks when incorporated into the food chain. Therefore, researchers are exploring means to convert WCO into biodiesel, which is an effective waste management solution and can also partially meet the global energy demand [110,111]. The transesterification of WCO using methanol as the solvent was investigated by Komintarachat et al. [112] using a variety of artificially produced SACs at a range of reaction times and temperatures. The WOx/Al2O3 catalyst had the highest level of catalytic activity compared to the other catalysts that were tested. Fig. 48 illustrates the influence that the weight ratio of methanol/oil has on the FAME conversion at the end of two hours of reaction time at a temperature of 110 °C. The activity profile shows that an increase in the weight ratio from 0.15 to 0.35 led to a dramatic rise in FAME yield, from 88% to 97.5%. When the weight ratio was 0.3, the highest percentage of conversion was recorded at 97.5%. Adding more methanol did not significantly increase the FAME output. Similar research yielded additional optimal circumstances. The results revealed that a methanol/WCO and a catalyst/WCO (ratio of 1%) provided a maximum yield of 97.5% FAME in 2 h at 110 °C. The possibility of recycling the catalyst was also explored to reduce production costs. To recover the SAC following the termination of the reaction, it was filtered, washed with petroleum ether, and dried at 60 °C for 4 h. According to Fig. 49 , the drop in FAME output was still rather minor after three reuses. However, after the fourth usage, there were noticeable declines in activity. Conclusions drawn from this study suggest that the WOx/Al2O3 catalyst can be deployed in both the laboratory and large-scale industrial biodiesel production. 27 Corncob-based SAC Corncob lignocellulose is an ideal source for various biorefinery objectives due to its high xylan content and low extractives and ash content. The unique structure of the corncob makes it more amenable to pretreatment methods relative to other types of biomass. With proper pretreatment, up to 95% cellulose recovery, 100% hemicellulose solubilization, and 99% delignification can be achieved. Thus, chemical platforms derived from corncobs have been applied in a variety of ways, from traditional to emerging products such as supercapacitors [113]. Hussain et al. [114] impregnated corncobs with phosphoric acid, then carbonated and sulfonated them to create SACs. The surface area, acid density, and pore volume of catalysts were determined through characterization. In addition, the factors that affect the esterification of OA were investigated, including the carbonization time and temperature, the sulfonation time and temperature, and the impregnation time and ratio. As an added measure, the catalyst's efficacy in esterifying FFA found in Karanja oil and fatty acids (palmitic acid and OA) was examined over a range of reaction conditions. Experiments reveal that both OA and palmitic acid conversions improve as reaction temperature rises (Fig. 50 ); 96.5% and 97.5% conversion to OA and palmitic acid, respectively, were measured in duration of 4 h at 65 °C. In addition, research into the molar ratio of the reactants revealed that a ratio of 1:10 significantly improves conversions from OA to 98.9% and from palmitic acid to 99.6%. Furthermore, the conversion of OA rises from 78.6% to 98.4% and that of palmitic acid rises from 78.3% to 98.5% when the catalyst amount is raised from 5wt.% to 10wt.%. However, the conversion did not noticeably improve after the catalyst loading increased to over 10%wt. To test the catalyst's recyclability, methanol and OA were used in a model reaction. At 65 °C, a 1:10 molar ratio of OA/methanol and a 10wt.% catalyst loading were used in the OA/methanol reaction. Once the reaction was complete, the reaction mass was removed and filtered through a filter to retrieve the catalyst. The catalyst was then dried at 90 °C under vacuum for 3 h after being washed with a solvent. It was then utilized in the subsequent cycle of esterification. As can be seen in Fig. 51 , n-hexane is the most effective regenerant for the current catalyst, maintaining a conversion of over 90% to OA over 20 regeneration cycles. The present catalyst was found to be superior to other documented catalysts in terms of its ability to make biodiesel in a shorter time period and at a moderate reaction temperature. In addition to being an effective catalyst for esterification, it also has the added benefit of requiring less methanol. 28 Graphene-like nanoporous carbons (GNCs) The graphene-based nanomaterials function as innovative carbon materials. The unique structures of these materials, comprising nanosheets, mechanical and thermal stability, and controlled wettability, have been recognized by physicists, chemists, and materials scientists. Consequently, these materials are well suited for deployment as solid acidic catalysts or catalyst supports. They are ideal candidates in view of their ability to significantly reduce mass transfer limitations, increase the degree of active site exposure, and enhance catalyst recyclability in various reactions [115,116]. By reacting nitrogen-containing GNCs with 1,3-propanesultone and then ion-exchanging with H2SO4 or HSO3CF3, Liu et al. [117] successfully manufactured bifunctional GNC‒SO3H‒ILs with powerful AILs and sulfonic groups (Fig. 52 ). Carbonization of glucose, melamine, or dicyandiamide yields GNCs, which requires the introduction of nitrogen for the successful grafting of AILs and the sulfonic group. The resultant GNC‒SO3H‒ILs takes advantage of controlled acidity, acceptable dispersion, nanosheet architecture, and abundant nanopores. A number of catalysts were tested for their ability to catalyze the transesterification of tripalmitin with methanol in different reaction time, and their results are depicted in Fig. 53 . Compared to Amberlyst 15, SBA‒15‒SO3H, and H3PW12O40, GNC‒[C3N][SO3CF3] exhibited much superior catalytic performance. Biodiesel (methyl palmitate) yielded 78.8% after 10 h of reaction when catalyzed by GNC‒[C3N][SO3CF3], compared to 39.7%, 50.5%, and 51.6%, by Amberlyst 15, SBA‒15‒SO3H, and H3PW12O40, respectively. GNC‒[C3N][SO3CF3]-catalyzed methyl yield of palmitate reached 88.5% by extending the reaction duration to 14 h. The results were quite similar to those obtained with [C3vim][SO3CF3] as a homogeneous AIL with an 89.8% yield. By comparison, the biodiesel yields from Amberlyst 15, SBA‒15‒SO3H, and H3PW12O40 were 53.6%, 60.8%, and 64.1%, respectively. The unique nanosheet structure, numerous nanopores, regulated acidity, high dispersion, and strong network stability of GNC‒[C3N][SO3CF3] appear to have contributed to the massive improvement in catalytic efficacy observed during the biomass transformation. The preparation of GNC‒[C3N][SO3CF3] may pave the way for a more efficient method of synthesizing GNC-based SACs with excellent efficiency and a long life for biomass conversion, which may have far-reaching implications for the use of graphene-based nanomaterials in biofuel exploitation. 29 SO3H-bearing amorphous carbon This carbonaceous substance encompasses pliant polycyclic carbon nanosheets that feature SO3H, COOH, and phenolic hydroxyl (OH) groups embedded within a three-dimensional network. The substance can be easily synthesized by partially carbonizing natural organic materials, like cellulose, starch, or sugar, followed by sulfonating the resultant amorphous carbon. The hydrophilic nature of the carbon material enables it to imbibe abundant quantities of hydrophilic molecules, including water, into its bulk owing to the high density of hydrophilic functional groups attached to the malleable carbon sheets. This property allows reactants in solution to conveniently access the SO3H groups present in the carbon material derived from sugar, thus leading to exceptional catalytic activity, notwithstanding the low surface area [118,119]. As a unique, powerful, and stable SAC, Nakajima et al. [120] developed a carbon SAC having a high density of sulfonic acid groups (‒SO3H). To create novel solid acids, these researchers have taken a different approach, using amorphous carbon materials comprised of tiny polycyclic aromatic carbon sheets with connected ‒SO3H groups. This method is straightforward and enables the use of solvent-soluble sulfoaromatic hydrocarbons (like naphthalene sulfonic acid and benzene sulfonic acid) as insoluble solid acids. In Fig. 54 , the results of the solid-state cross-polarization magic angle spinning carbon-13 nuclear magnetic resonance (CP/MAS 13C NMR) test are presented. As can be seen in Fig. 54a, the data indicate that sp2-carbons, rather than sp3-carbons, serve as the connecting link between the carbon sheets.
