The carbon precursors acquired at temperatures higher than 550 °C can also be sulfonated to produce amorphous carbon in the form of small carbon sheets of the same size as those generated at temperatures lower than 450 °C. However, the absence of phenolic ‒COOH and ‒OH groups causes the carbon sheets to cross-link more strongly in sp2 configuration, and the number of ‒SO3H groups attached to the sheets is only about half that of the samples carbonized at temperatures lower than 450 °C. (Fig. 54b). Fig. 55 illustrates a simplified flowchart of one method for making biodiesel from virgin vegetable oil. Using both the transesterification of triglycerides and the esterification of higher fatty acids, this figure shows how biodiesel is made. Esterification catalyzed by acid is the most widely used technique, followed by transesterification catalyzed by base. The employment of homogenous or soluble acid and base catalysts in this process, as in the synthesis of conventional biodiesel, results in a significant environmental impact. Despite having strong catalytic performance for the esterification of higher fatty acids, homogenous acid catalysts like H2SO4 need further treatment in the form of neutralization, besides expensive and ineffective catalyst separation. Large energy consumption is also caused by the transesterification of triglycerides in the product produced by esterification, which uses soluble base catalysts like KOH. In terms of catalytic performance and processing, the material is still far from being a substitute catalyst for the homogeneous Brønsted acids. More enhancements need to be made before amorphous carbon with SO3H groups can replace the homogeneous acids. 30 Bagasse-based solid acid (BBSA) The sugar milling industry generates bagasse, which is a by-product and also serves as an essential fuel source for the industry. The chemical composition and natural, biodegradable properties of bagasse have sparked interest in its potential as a versatile ingredient in composite materials. The search for eco-friendly and affordable materials has driven material science researchers to explore green materials with minimal environmental impact [121,122]. Through the sulfonation and partial carbonization of bagasse powder, Savaliya et al. [123] created the BBSA catalyst, which is deployed in the esterification of soap stock oil to prepare biodiesel. Fig. 56 illustrates the general reaction pathway for the esterification of soap stock oil to biodiesel. In addition, Fig. 57 presents a general plan to produce a SAC using bagasse powder. The generated catalyst was examined for the esterification of soap stock oil. The best reaction conditions within the ranges of the chosen parameters were determined to be 11 h of reaction duration, 65 °C reaction temperature, a ratio of 1:15 soap stock oil/methanol, and 5wt.% catalyst loading, resulting in a maximal FFA conversion of 97.2%. Reusability of the synthesized catalyst was also studied, wherein the synthesized catalysts could be used 3 times without significantly losing their activity. This study also examined the fuel qualities of soap stock biodiesel and compared them to ASTM requirements. For doing so, the hydrometer technique (ASTM: D1298) was used to measure the density of the biodiesel made from soap stock. The Pensky-Martin closed cup tester (ASTM: D93) was used to determine the flash point. The Aditya 01 viscometer bath was utilized to measure both kinematic and shear viscosities (ASTM: D445). Using the AFIDA 2805 cetane number analyzer, the cetane number (ASTM: D613) was determined. The Stanhope-Seta cloud point analyzer was utilized for measuring the cloud point (ASTM: D2500). The results show that all fuel qualities fall within the standards set by ASTM. The catalyst helps to decrease the expenses associated with post-reaction procedures, such as the separation and retrieval of unconsumed alcohol, which can inflate the final cost of biodiesel. To sum up, the application of a BBSA catalyst to soap stock oil can lead to the cost-efficient production of biodiesel. 31 SiO2@Cs‒SO3H Cs, a biopolymer comprising natural polysaccharides, has drawn significant interest in wide ranging applications in engineering and scientific fields. In studies on chemical synthesis reactions, metal extraction, and fuel cells based on electrolytes, Cs have been extensively explored. Due to their capacity to create open-network, high-surface-area hydrogels with basic surface sites that are easily accessible, Cs-based materials have been deployed not just as macrochelating ligands for active metal catalysts but also as supports to disperse nanosized particles and directly as organocatalysts as well [124,125]. With nano-sized SiO2 as the solid support and p-toluenesulfonic acid as the sulfonation reagent, Zhang et al. [126] created the novel SiO2@Cs‒SO3H SAC. For this investigation, a straightforward, mild, and eco-friendly synthetic method was chosen (Fig. 58 ). The effect of temperature on biodiesel production was measured between 70 °C and 110 °C, as depicted in Fig. 59 a. The biodiesel output was measured and was shown to rise steadily with an increase in temperature from 70 °C to 90 °C, ultimately reaching well over 90%. Because of the decrease in yield with increasing temperature, a temperature of 90 °C was chosen for the reaction. At 90 °C, a methanol/OA molar ratio of 30:1, and a catalyst loading of 6wt.%, the biodiesel production yield of 96% was reached after 4 h of processing time (Fig. 59b); ideal response time was therefore found to be 4 h. According to Figs. 59c and d, the best values for the catalyst loading and the methanol/OA molar ratio were also determined to be 6wt.% and 30:1, respectively. The catalyst showed excellent recyclability, with a biodiesel yield of 87% still achievable after 5 runs. In brief, the SiO2@Cs‒SO3H SAC exhibited outstanding catalytic performance for the esterification of FFAs, indicating a promising future in the field of biodiesel generation. The utilization of SACs has become an emerging field for biodiesel production [127]. However, various issues that limit the high efficiency of these catalysts, including limited reactivity, durability, and stability under stern reaction conditions, still remain; their loss of activity and recyclability must be addressed. To produce effective SACs, it is necessary to combine hybrid materials with optimal properties. Because each nanostructured material (e.g., 2D, hybrid, MOFs, NPs, porous, etc.) has distinctive characteristics, combining them with acidic catalytic properties may result in customized SACs with suitable catalyst parameters. Tables 1 and 2 provide a comparison of the illustrated catalysts for the esterification of lauric acid with methanol and ethanol [56,128-135]. Lowe and colleagues reviewed sulfated SACs derived from inexpensive raw materials for the production of biodiesel [136]. Su et al. tabulated some instances of mesoporous (organo)silica SACs modified with sulfonic acid and their use in esterification and transesterification processes of WCOs for the production of biodiesel in a review article. They realized multiple molecular environments for the SACs, including activity changes based on the quantity, potency, and textural characteristics of the acid sites [127]. Table 3 assesses the catalytic performance of a few chosen SACs from the literature for producing FAME from WCO feedstock. The results demonstrate that although product yields can vary, they are impacted by variables such reaction conditions, catalyst loading, and properties [44,47,137-145]. The differences and similarities appear not to have a specific predictive pattern and depend extensively on the conditions of reaction, intrinsic features, approaches to the preparation of catalysts, and parameters such as catalyst loading, surface area, porosity, shape, size, composition, and so on. 32 Conclusions, outlooks, and perspectives Homogeneous catalysts have high reaction rates and yields at low operating temperatures and pressures. However, they are sensitive to the FFA concentration of the oil, which results in the formation of undesirable by-products, such as soaps, making the purification process challenging and the catalysts unfeasible for subsequent applications. To alleviate these issues and transform the current biodiesel manufacturing methods to yield inexpensive commercial products, heterogeneous catalysts are being explored, although a wide variety of SACs for producing biodiesel are still being investigated on a laboratory scale. As predicted, heterogeneous catalysts perform better under high temperature and pressure settings than their homogeneous counterparts. When it comes to the production of biodiesel, SACs are among the most commonly used types of catalysts. They are capable of catalyzing both esterification and transesterification concurrently because of their stability in the presence of water and FFA. The main issues that prevent their steady operations for biodiesel generation are the leaching of active sites and the unfavorable catalyst morphologies. Some other drawbacks include low reaction rates and unstable catalytic activity, which also need to be addressed. This review provides a concise overview of the latest developments in the synthesis and application of heterogeneous SACs derived from environmentally friendly feedstock. Heterogeneous SACs show considerable promise for use in industrial biodiesel production. Evidence from this compilation shows that catalysts need to meet specific criteria to be employed in commercial applications. These include being inexpensive to create, highly active catalyst, that is reusable. Harmful chemicals and ecological damages can also be greatly avoided in the biodiesel synthesis process by using heterogeneous catalysts made from natural materials. This overview summarizes and evaluates the current state of SAC research, progression, and implementation in the context of the esterification/transesterification processes. According to the examined literature, the SACs, like Ti(SO4)O, SO4/Fe‒Al‒TiO2, SWCNHs, Ti‒SBA‒15, La‒PW‒SiO2/SWCNTs, Al3+‒SO4 2−/MWCNTs, IL-grafted NH2‒UiO‒66, ZrFe‒SA‒SO3H, rGO‒SO3H, CaO‒Al2O3‒SiO2‒CaSO4, WOx/Al2O3, and SiO2@Cs‒SO3H, among others, achieved excellent results in biodiesel conversion/yield. High biodiesel conversion rates and recycling potential have been reported for many of these catalysts as well. Most heterogeneous catalysts, as well-known, are not stable over time, which prevents them from being widely deployed and commercialized. Therefore, the creation of suitable catalysts that are devoid of further cleaning procedures, the development of biodiesel preparative methods that proceed in fewer steps and/or require less refinement, and the deployment of ecologically friendly precursors are some of the prerequisite features that ought to be explored in the future. The incorporation of nanostructured materials has opened up significant prospects in the field of SAC research, thus circumventing some of those problematic challenges. However, despite the various benefits of SACs, such as durability, stability, and reusability, many of the discussed catalysts still need further improvements to overcome a variety of hindrances posed by their technical and large-scale preparation-associated higher costs, in addition to uneven and decaying SAC activity and poor chemo- and regio-selectivity. coredata.dc:description: Biodiesel obtained via the transesterification process, a reaction frequently involving catalysis by homogeneous or heterogeneous catalysts, has shown considerable potential as a supplement to petroleum-based diesel; heterogeneous catalysts in the transesterification of vegetable oils are of special interest as they are relatively safer for the environment besides being endowed with recycling and regeneration attributes. The deployment of heterogeneous catalysts, however, necessitates a higher concentration of catalyst, a greater molar ratio of alcohol to oil, and an elevated temperature and pressure to produce biodiesel. A variety of solid-acid catalysts (SACs) have been utilized in the production of biodiesel, represented by Ti(SO4)O, SO4/Fe‒Al‒TiO2, sulfonated single-wall carbon nanohorns, Ti‒SBA‒15, La‒PW‒SiO2/single-wall carbon nanotubes, ionic liquid grafted NH2‒UiO‒66, ZrFe‒SA‒SO3H, magnetic SACs, sulfonic-reduced graphene oxide, CaO‒Al2O3‒SiO2‒CaSO4, and SiO2@Cs‒SO3H, which are deliberated here. These catalysts are highlighted and discussed in view of their exceptional catalytic activity and recyclability, in addition to comments on the existing challenges and potential future perspectives of the SACs.
coredata.dc:title: Recent developments in solid acid catalysts for biodiesel production
